# The Wild West Elite: The Go-To Law Firms Of Texas, Colorado, And Utah
## Engaging these firms can help the tech startups, unicorns, and venture capitalists of the new economy avoid or contain problems down the road.
By [Above the Law](https://abovethelaw.com/author/above-the-law/)  
onDecember 6, 2016 at 1:02 PMDecember 6, 2016 at 1:03 PM
59
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/the-wild-west-elite-the-go-to-law-firms-of-texas-colorado-and-utah/&text=The%20Wild%20West%20Elite:%20The%20Go-To%20Law%20Firms%20Of%20Texas,%20Colorado,%20And%20Utah)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/the-wild-west-elite-the-go-to-law-firms-of-texas-colorado-and-utah/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/the-wild-west-elite-the-go-to-law-firms-of-texas-colorado-and-utah/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image by Andrew E. Russell)

[Lake Whillans](http://lakewhillans.com/), a leader in the field of litigation finance, supports innovative entrepreneurs and businesses across the country, including those in vital epicenters of tech innovation. Throughout the year, we have explored the legal markets in these hubs, each unique in its own right.

So far, we’ve looked at the “[White Sandal](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/05/the-white-sandal-elite-the-go-to-law-firms-of-silicon-valley/)” firms of Silicon Valley and “[Route 128 Elite](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/rt-128-elite-the-go-to-law-firms-of-boston/?rf=1)” of Greater Boston — both indisputable markets where all manner of innovation is thriving.

Today, we look to the states of the “Wild West” — including Texas, Colorado, and Utah — which are home to an impressive amount of startup activity. Depending on which survey you believe, either [Austin](http://www.austinchronicle.com/screens/2016-10-28/austin-as-tech-hub-myth-or-reality/) or [Boulder](http://www.inc.com/magazine/201312/boulder-colorado-fast-growing-business.html) can claim to lead the country in high-tech startups per capita. Meanwhile, the “Silicon Slopes” of Utah have emerged as a hotbed of entrepreneurship, with the U.S. Chamber of Commerce [recently ranking](https://www.uschamberfoundation.org/enterprisingstates/#UT) the state No. 1 in innovation.

The legal market in this vast region comprises both well-established Biglaw titans (e.g., Vinson & Elkins, Akin Gump) and a multitude of specialist boutiques and smaller firms with deep local roots and thriving practices in areas ranging from estate planning to restructuring to white collar defense. And in these hotbed cities of tech and startup activity, there’s also plenty of cutting-edge patent, IPO, and M&A work.

Continuing our series of tech hub round-ups, Lake Whillans presents this handy primer on the Go-To Law Firms of the Wild West. These firms not only can handle every transactional need, but they do anything from taxes to setting up HR review processes. Engaging these firms can help the tech startups, unicorns, and venture capitalists of the new economy avoid or contain problems down the road. Should legal issues arise, Lake Whillans can step in and help resolve them.

- Best Firm for One-Horned Horsey Creatures: [Wilson Sonsini](https://www.wsgr.com/WSGR/Default.aspx)


When you think you’re on to the next big thing but need investors to get your crazy idea off the ground, this is the firm you want in your corner. From the firm’s early days in Silicon Valley, the lawyers at Wilson Sonsini have dedicated themselves to backing innovators and emerging companies. Today, their expertise in representing venture-backed clients has expanded to the rest of the country, and their venture capital practice counts some heavy-hitting partners in Austin among their ranks. Well-versed in every stage of private-company growth, these are the lawyers you need to help make your pipe dream a reality.

- Best Firm for Patenting Your Algorithm or Application: [Jackson Walker](https://www.jw.com)


With Texas roots that date back over a century, the lawyers at Jackson Walker know the ins and outs of the regulations affecting Texas businesses. The firm has built up a prominent patent practice, highly skilled at helping clients navigate the confusing waters of patent procurement. From the initial application to defending your patent in court, these lawyers have what it takes to protect your innovations. And when the chips are down, they’ve got the chops to enforce your rights against infringers through complex litigation and dispute resolution.

- Best Firm for Trademarking the Logo You Think Is So Cool: [Bryan Cave](https://www.bryancave.com/en/index.html)


With multiple offices in Texas and Colorado, this firm is dedicated to securing the trademark rights of companies throughout the West. Recognizing that trademarks are among a company’s most valuable assets, the firm’s trademark practice has dedicated itself to protecting company branding on a global scale. From trademark procurement to complex trademark prosecution, the firm’s lawyers have a proven track record of safeguarding their clients’ brand identities in Texas and around the world.

- Best Firm for Suing the Bigger Company That Stole Your Intellectual Property: [Kilpatrick Townsend](http://www.kilpatricktownsend.com)


Established in 1995, the Denver office of Kilpatrick Townsend has developed into one of the largest intellectual property practices in Colorado. With clients ranging from local startups to global corporations, the firm is dedicated to protecting innovation in Colorado’s key industries, from aerospace to telecommunications. The firm’s lawyers have been consistently recognized as the top intellectual property practitioners in the state, and they have what it takes to defend and protect your innovations through all phases of litigation. Whether it’s a trademark appeal or a complex patent infringement case, this is a shop you want to call when your intellectual property rights are on the line.

- Best Firm for When You Actually Find Yourself in a Courtroom: [Norton Rose Fulbright](http://www.nortonrosefulbright.com/us/)


With offices in Austin, Dallas, Denver, and Houston, this firm has dominated the region when it comes to handling complex commercial disputes. Dedicated to fighting for the needs of their clients, the firm’s lawyers know their way around a courtroom. From jury trials to appeals, the attorneys at Norton Rose Fulbright have a proven track record in courts and tribunals across the country, on both a federal and state level. Whatever issues your commercial dispute may involve, these lawyers will handle it every step of the way. When the stakes are high, this is the firm you want to call.

- Best Firm for Keeping That Glass Ceiling Off: [Akin Gump](https://www.akingump.com/en/index.html)


Specializing in the most complex of labor and employment issues, Akin Gump has consistently been recognized as a leader in the field. From discrimination claims to OSHA enforcement actions to wage-and-hour lawsuits, this firm handles it all. The firm’s labor and employment attorneys are well-versed in the laws and regulations today’s employers face. With an increased national focus on workplace discrimination and equal pay, your company needs the best lawyers available seeing that you don’t run afoul of the law. Akin Gump’s attorneys are the team you need to help you avoid the risk of litigation and adopt employment practices that will give you a competitive advantage.

- Best Firm for Helping You Get Office Space: [Davis Graham & Stubbs](https://www.dgslaw.com)


Headquartered in Denver, Davis Graham & Stubbs has been providing superior business law advice for more than a century and offers some of the most comprehensive real estate services in the Mountain West. Whether you’re looking for commercial, office or retail space, this firm has you covered. Representing players on both sides of the table, these lawyers have the experience necessary to handle your needs every step of the way, from lease negotiation to construction financing. They not only have the real estate know-how to get your business up and running, they also have the litigation chops needed to protect your interests when your property rights are on the line.

- Best Firm to Keep You Out Of Prison: [DeGuerin, Dickson & Ward](http://www.deguerin.com)


Having famously represented the likes of cult leader David Koresh, accused murderer Robert Durst, and House Majority Leader Tom Delay, there’s no bigger player in the Texas criminal defense game than Dick DeGuerin. He’s the first choice for those facing heat in the Lone Star State, from U.S. senators to Enron bankers. DeGuerin’s firm focuses on criminal defense work and has a proven track record for success in the courtroom, from celebrity cases to minor offenses. Even if you’re not famous, Dick DeGuerin is the guy you want to call when you’re facing possible time in the Texas slammer.

- Best Firm to Win the Trial Over Your Intellectual Property: [Kirton McConkie](http://www.kmclaw.com)


One of the largest intellectual property firms in the region, the IP attorneys at Kirton McConkie offer an unrivaled depth of legal experience when it comes to protecting your rights and interests. Heavy hitters in both the domestic and international arenas, these lawyers are adept at tackling any intellectual property matters that come their way. From biotech to pharmaceuticals, the firm has handled the complex intellectual property portfolios of some of the world’s largest corporations. Boasting an impressive roster of attorneys with scientific backgrounds, Kirton McConkie excels in the courtroom, deftly handling the most complicated of trademark, trade dress, and patent litigations.

- Best Firm for When You Need Estate Planning After Your IPO: [Hutchinson Black and Cook](http://www.hbcboulder.com)


For more than 125 years, Hutchinson Black and Cook has been the go-to law firm for Boulder companies. Its thriving will, trusts and estates practice is capable of handling the most complex of estate planning needs. Offering an unprecedented level of client service, the firm’s attorneys can help you plan every aspect of your estate, from powers of attorney to charitable giving to guardianship arrangements. They’ll even handle your probate and litigation needs. When it comes to something as important as planning for your future, this is the firm you can trust.

- Best Firm to Advise Minority Shareholders: [Fryar Law Firm](http://www.shareholderoppression.com)


Specializing in shareholder oppression cases, this niche Houston boutique firm is dedicated to protecting shareholder interests and boasts a depth of business law knowledge that belies the firm’s small size. Experts in the ever-changing legal landscape governing small business ownership, these lawyers will fight for your rights when you feel you’re being marginalized by other shareholders. With a focus on representing entrepreneurs and business owners in disputes among partners, the firm’s utmost goal is to get you a fair resolution. When you’re facing a falling out with your business partner, these are the lawyers you want in your corner.

- Best Firm to Independently Advise the Board of Directors: [Andrews Kurth Kenyon LLP](https://www.andrewskurth.com)


With offices in Austin, Houston, Dallas, and The Woodlands, Andrews Kurth has Texas covered when it comes to advising companies on corporate governance matters. Recognized as one of the country’s top securities law firms, these attorneys have the legal know-how to guide their clients through the confusing landscape of corporate regulation. The firm’s attorneys specialize in working one-on-one with company boards of directors to develop client-specific best practices. Whether it’s a question of reporting requirements, fiduciary duties or employment policies, these are the people to consult to make sure you’re on the up and up.

- Best Firm to Help You Make Sure You Have Capital to Keep the Lights On Until Daybreak: [Cooley](https://www.cooley.com)


Claiming to have unrivaled access to the world’s most influential venture capital investors, Cooley has represented thousands of billion-dollar startups and some of the world’s top innovators. For the past decade, the firm has consistently been recognized as the go-to shop for VC-backed companies going public. The firm has expanded its expertise to Colorado, specializing in helping local emerging companies through all stages of their corporate existence. These are the lawyers to consult if you’re worried about having the funds to keep your company up and running.

- Best Firm for Incorporating Your Two-Person Company Because Somebody Told You There Were Tax Benefits: [Snell & Wilmer](https://www.swlaw.com)


With offices in Denver and Salt Lake City, Snell & Welmer is the go-to firm for entrepreneurs and emerging businesses in the West. Known as much for their client-centered service as for their deep business-law knowledge, the firm is sympathetic to the struggles and challenges involved in starting up a business. They offer cost-effective legal solutions to clients in a wide range of industries. Whether you’re an internet startup or a retail shop, the lawyers at Snell & Wilmer will help you choose the business setup that’s right for you.

- Best Firm for Planning (or Avoiding) the Re-Startup: [Clyde Snow](http://www.clydesnow.com)


Based out of the firm’s Salt Lake City office, the lawyers at Clyde Snow deftly handle all aspects of Chapter 7 and Chapter 11 matters. Offering a breadth of experience in representing parties on both sides of bankruptcy matters, the firm is the go-to choice for debtors and creditors alike. If bankruptcy or reorganization can’t be avoided, the lawyers at Clyde Snow have the skills to prosecute and defend bankruptcy-related claims, and they have a proven track record of getting the best possible results for their clients.

- Best Firm to Keep You Out of E-Discovery Hell: [Jones Day](http://www.jonesday.com)


It’s undeniable that technology has irreversibly changed the landscape of litigation. E-discovery is a crucial factor that can make or break your case, and you need lawyers who are skilled at handling it. Jones Day offers some of the deepest experience out there when it comes to all aspects of e-discovery. With several of the firm’s key e-discovery players based out of Dallas and Houston, Jones Day has companies in the Lone Star State covered. From document retention to foreign-language document review, these are the lawyers you can rely on to handle all your e-discovery needs.

- Best Firm for When You Are Ready to Get into the Asian Market: [Vinson & Elkins](https://www.velaw.com)


A long-time heavyweight in the Texas legal arena, few Lone Star firms can rival Vinson & Elkins when it comes to knowing the Asian market. Offering more than 30 years’ experience representing clients throughout Asia, the firm has offices on the ground in Beijing, Hong Kong, Taipei, and Tokyo. Their attorneys are adept at handling all aspects of complex transactions and disputes, both for clients looking to do business in Asia and Asian clients looking to invest abroad. The firm’s proven track record for representing top-tier global clients makes them the clear choice for anyone looking to enter the Asian market.

- Best Firm for Designing Your Employee Stock-Option Plan: [Stoel Rives](https://www.stoel.com)


Offering vast experience in all aspects of employee benefits law, the attorneys at Stoel Rives are experts when it comes to implementing employee stock ownership plans. With a benefits practice based out of the firm’s Salt Lake City office, Stoel Rives serves major clients in a broad range of industries doing business throughout the country. Whether you’re in entertainment or energy, these lawyers can help you implement stock-option plans and other employee benefits that best suit the specific needs of your company. From health insurance to retirement plans to executive compensation, these folks have you covered.

- Best Firm for Lobbying Congress in Your Favor: [Locke Lord](http://www.lockelord.com)


When Texas companies want their voices heard in Washington, D.C., they turn to Locke Lord. Consistently recognized as the top law firm lobbying practice in the Lone Star State, Locke Lord has cornered the market on Texas public advocacy. The firm’s lawyers know their way around Capitol Hill and are no strangers to the legislative halls in Austin. Locke Lord’s public law practice is led by none other than Robert Miller, a dedicated attorney who has been universally recognized a one of the top lobbyists in Texas and one of the best government relations lawyers in the country. When legislation can make or break your business, this is the guy you call.

- Best Jack-of-All-Trades Firm for High-Growth Companies: [Baker Botts](http://www.bakerbotts.com)


Texas roots don’t get much deeper than those at Baker Botts. Since its founding in Houston in the 1840s, the firm has exploded to become one of the world’s leading full-service law practices. Serving a broad range of industries with an increasing focus on emerging technologies, the firm’s expertise is spread across 15 offices around the globe. From banking and finance to complex commercial litigation, there’s no legal matter you can throw at this business law powerhouse that they can’t handle. Baker Botts is the go-to firm for Texas companies looking to be competitive in today’s market.

# Biglaw Firm Dumps Its Problematic Pension To Find Merger Partner
## Won’t someone, anyone merge with Stroock now?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onAugust 8, 2023 at 12:18 PMAugust 8, 2023 at 9:50 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/biglaw-firm-dumps-its-problematic-pension-to-find-merger-partner/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Dumps%20Its%20Problematic%20Pension%20To%20Find%20Merger%20Partner)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/biglaw-firm-dumps-its-problematic-pension-to-find-merger-partner/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/biglaw-firm-dumps-its-problematic-pension-to-find-merger-partner/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
As more and more partners head for the exits, Stroock & Stroock & Lavan’s urge to merge has grown even stronger, so much so that the firm was willing to change its ways (i.e., its pension liabilities) to find the right partner.

When we last checked in with Stroock, the firm had authorized a vote of the retired partners to [dump its pension obligations](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/biglaw-firm-tries-to-dump-its-pension-plan-to-become-more-eligible-merger-partner/) through a buyout. But even with the vote underway, still more partners departed from the firm, with the latest being a group of five restructuring partners headed to Morgan Lewis.

But now, Stroock seems to have made positive progress on becoming a more attractive merger partner. The [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/08/07/stroock-loses-bankruptcy-chair-in-five-partner-exit-to-morgan-lewis/) has the details:

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…

[T]he law firm said on Monday it has secured the vote to end its pension obligation and it is optimistic about reaching a merger. …

While the retirees were due to vote by Tuesday this week, Stroock indicated on Monday that they approved it.

The firm offered the following statement to Am Law: “Now having secured the votes needed to end our pension obligation, we are optimistic about achieving a desired merger.”

The firm has previously been involved in merger talks with McGuireWoods, Steptoe & Johnson, Squire Patton Boggs, and Nixon Peabody, but nothing has worked out. Maybe there’s finally some hope for the firm now that it’s nixed its pension problems.

# Just Another Roll Of The Dice
## David Cambria gambles big at Baker McKenzie.
By Brad Blickstein  
onJuly 24, 2018 at 3:15 PMJuly 24, 2018 at 2:32 PM
15
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/07/just-another-roll-of-the-dice/&text=Just%20Another%20Roll%20Of%20The%20Dice)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/07/just-another-roll-of-the-dice/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/07/just-another-roll-of-the-dice/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
When I met David Cambria back in 2007, we hit it off immediately. Not only did I like him very much, but I was thrilled to find an expert who would talk to me about the ins and outs of legal operations. For David’s part, I think he was happy to find someone — anyone — who cared about his role and was interested in helping others see the value it can deliver.

It may have been at that very first lunch that we agreed to collaborate on the first Survey of Law Department Operations. Since then, we’ve put out 10 more, spoken on the same panel maybe a dozen times, thought about starting a business together, and almost got in a fight with some guy who couldn’t find the mosh pit at a Frank Turner show. (Hint: It’s right in front of the stage.)

Still, I was a bit shocked when he called me up last month and told me he was moving to Baker McKenzie.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Perhaps I shouldn’t have been surprised. David’s been telling me for a year that law firms are finally ready for the type of changes he’s been working towards and advocating for in-house. That if law departments are changing the way they are buying, then law firms must change the way they are delivering. I just never thought he’d jump. “Law firms are where corporate law departments were 10-15 years ago,” he says. “So to have the opportunity to shape and drive that change was appealing.”

I see his point. David has spent the better part of his career helping law departments align with their business units. “Legal operations is a set of disciplines that facilitate the delivery of legal advice,” he says. So if law departments can develop the discipline to better serve their clients, why can’t a law firm develop the discipline to serve theirs?

One reason is that they are not really incentivized to. According to the [2017 Law Department Operations Survey](http://blicksteingroup.com/ldo-survey/), published in cooperation with Consilio, less than a third of respondents describe their law firms as innovative, but few are holding their feet to the fire.

It’s easy to forget that a decade ago, law departments were not incentivized to either. A general counsel could usually get the finance team to stand down just by saying “but legal is different” or “it’s too risky.” Eventually, the finance and business units — spurred on by the Great Recession — got fed up and law departments were forced to react and that reaction required the skill set of the LDO professional.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)

### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Maybe we are, in fact, at the point where law firms will start to feel the need to leverage process improvements and technology implementations and new pricing models. “I’ve worked with a lot of law firms, and there are pockets — specific attorneys or practice areas — that really get it. But so far it hasn’t been scalable. We need to change the DNA of the law firm and that’s what I’m trying to do here at Baker.”


David Cambria

The gamble, of course, is whether he can make it work. Baker McKenzie is almost 70 years old and has almost 5,000 lawyers. It’s not exactly a nimble startup. And unlike at a law department, firms are not managed hierarchically. It might be difficult for in-house counsel to go against the express wishes of the general counsel (and their hand-picked LDO). Law firm partners do it all the time. So will it work?

“I’ve been asking myself that question a lot. But my discussions with Baker happened over a long period of time and they showed themselves to be willing to really embrace legal ops. They already have a service center in Belfast for more routine work and a growing legal project management function that’s gaining traction with clients. There had already been a lot of innovation and they had already implemented a lot of new different technology. And last year, they elected a managing partner in North America who ran on a platform of building out the firm’s professional services to enable the firm to do more than just deliver legal advice. I feel really optimistic because the indicators are in place.”

A dozen years ago, David and I sat in a hotel restaurant and he said the same thing about law department operations. Can he roll another 7 or 11? I wouldn’t bet against it.

# Visionary Leadership In Times Of Change
## Seven ways you can set your team up for success.
By STEPHANIE COREY  
onNovember 15, 2023 at 12:20 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/visionary-leadership-in-times-of-change/&text=Visionary%20Leadership%20In%20Times%20Of%20Change)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/visionary-leadership-in-times-of-change/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/visionary-leadership-in-times-of-change/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The true measure of an effective legal operations leader with staying power is how she pivots away from traditional management and toward a new vision for the industry. The key to this transformation lies in recognizing this unique moment and seizing its potential.

Visionary leaders stand out by staying ahead of the curve, identifying opportunities that remain invisible to others, and maintaining clarity in the face of uncertainty. They are strategic thinkers who can execute pragmatically, balancing long-term vision with the demands of daily operations. For example, visionary leaders do not follow the generic trend regarding generative artificial intelligence. Instead, they create custom use cases and learn how to implement them to improve client satisfaction and operational efficiency. 

While it’s clear that visionary leaders possess many unique attributes, achieving this type of leadership in practice is not easy. A key part of the equation is learning to manage your organization’s day-to-day operations and the need for innovation simultaneously. As Ferring Pharmaceutical’s Chief Legal Officer, Curt McDaniel, would say, “It’s a blend of reaching for the stars and working step by step to get there.” This requires a transformative, multi-pronged strategy that leaves a lasting impact on the organization.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
In addition, all great leaders have support in their shared vision. Regarding Legal Ops leadership, the support of the Chief Legal Officer and the General Counsel is essential. The CLO/GC should be a united front with the head of Legal Ops and help to define the path forward. Since Legal is at the front line of change and addresses the challenges and resistance accompanying change, support from the top is essential to help clear the way. 

Even great leaders with support from the top can find this process challenging, so here are a few more ways to set your teams up for success. 

- Cultivate a Culture of Innovation. Innovation is not a solo endeavor, as it thrives in the fertile soil of collaboration and open dialogue. Engage your team in robust discussions, even if it means challenging the status quo. One way to encourage this is to hold regular ‘Innovation Labs,’ where team members of all levels brainstorm solutions to operational challenges, with the best ideas recognized and rewarded.
- Start With The Why. When the CLO/GC clearly articulates the need behind proposed changes compellingly, it eases worry and avoids unnecessary distractions later in the process. Define the needed services and approach the process as if you are running a business (because you are!). Ask questions upfront and address concerns. This open dialogue helps reduce fear and hesitation as you begin. Come back to The Why throughout the process to remind teams of the ultimate goal.
- Embrace Risk in a Risk-Averse Field. There is no innovation without risk, yet the legal domain remains cautious. Create an environment where calculated risk-taking is supported and celebrated. Celebrate the team members who dare to think differently and are willing to test new waters.
- Anticipate Resistance With Proactive Change Management. Effective change management anticipates and addresses resistance head-on. Develop strategies to navigate potential obstacles and ensure smooth transitions. A proactive stance on change management prepares the organization for the expected and unforeseen, maintaining agility and resilience.
- Enable Agility Through Clear Communication and Training. Clarity in communication is paramount. Articulate the vision and the rationale for changes clearly, ensuring alignment across the organization. Complement this with robust training programs that prepare your team for new systems and processes. This dual approach fosters adaptability and ensures everyone can handle the changes ahead.
- Bring the Team on the Journey Together. It’s essential to bring the team along with you on this journey of change, starting with meeting them where they are. Talk, listen, and demonstrate that concerns are heard. Involve your people in the change process so they have ownership of it. Change affects everyone in different ways, so by going through this process, you will understand their worldview and how the change affects them personally. From there, you can show individuals how they will benefit from a new approach, and they have the opportunity to embrace and share this vision, too.
- Lead by Example. As a leader, your actions set the tone for the organization, and leading by example is key. Demonstrate your commitment to innovation and change to inspire your team to follow suit. Be the first to embrace new tools and methodologies and hold yourself accountable for desired changes. Your example will motivate your team and create a ripple effect of proactive change throughout the organization. 
The legal sector’s path forward is charted by those willing to embrace visionary leadership. By promoting open dialogue, encouraging risk-taking, leading by example, and managing change proactively, you can ensure your organization adapts to change and thrives. The future is being written now, so Legal Ops leaders can be the authors of a narrative that speaks to a collective potential to innovate and excel.

# Lawyers Should Make It Easier For Clients To Pay Them
## Run-of-the-mill clients may face more challenges paying on time if the law firm only allows clients to pay by check.
By [Jordan Rothman](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jordanrothman/)  
onJanuary 12, 2024 at 10:47 AMJanuary 17, 2024 at 11:46 AM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/lawyers-should-make-it-easier-for-clients-to-pay-them/&text=Lawyers%20Should%20Make%20It%20Easier%20For%20Clients%20To%20Pay%20Them)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/lawyers-should-make-it-easier-for-clients-to-pay-them/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/lawyers-should-make-it-easier-for-clients-to-pay-them/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
I basically had to start from scratch when establishing billing practices after I launched my own practice, and I learned quickly which methods worked best to ensure that clients paid their invoices on time. One of the most important facts that I discovered about the collections process is that the easier it is for clients to pay, the more likely it is that the lawyer will be timely paid. Although that may seem self-evident, many lawyers allow clients to pay legal fees in only one or two burdensome ways, and that can impact how quickly bills are paid.

I retained a few lawyers in the past for various legal matters that I needed help with in my life. These lawyers worked at small shops, and most law firms that handle real estate closings, traffic tickets, and other matters during which individuals need to engage counsel are smaller operations. Every time I retained a lawyer in my personal life, the only way I could pay them was to mail a check to their office.

This presented problems. Before I operated my own law practice, I did not mail anything on a regular basis and, thus, rarely had stamps. Moreover, I also inconsistently had checks. I pay for pretty much everything online, and I used one checkbook for almost a decade. When I ran out of checks, it took me a very long time to order new ones because I did not really need them.

As a result, I was not the best client when it came time to pay my lawyer. It took me time to get my act together to secure the stamps and checks to pay my attorney, since there was no way that I could pay my lawyer in a quicker fashion. As a lawyer myself, I understand how important it is to pay lawyers (and others) on time, and I couldn’t help but think that run-of-the-mill clients would face more challenges paying on time if the law firm only allowed clients to pay by check.

When I started my own law firm, I resolved that I would make it as easy as possible for clients to pay their bills. My firm offers clients several ways to send payments. Clients can drop a check in the mail for us, and some of our clients do this on a regular basis. However, most of our clients pay their bills by credit card. Our invoices have a link and a QR code that let clients pay their invoices by credit card in just a few clicks. Clients who have their credit card information saved on their computers might only require a few seconds to pay their bills. Usually, the bills that are paid soon after they are issued are the ones paid by credit card since clients can easily take care of the invoices.

Credit card companies charge relatively high fees, which my firm eats for the sake of convenience to the client. Sometimes, if clients are paying a larger bill, we wish that the bills would not be paid by credit card since credit card fees may take away hundreds of dollars that would otherwise end up in our pockets. However, the convenience more than makes up for it. Some of our more savvy clients pay by bank transfer, which is also preferable, since this usually does not come with the same amount of fees as credit cards.

In any case, providing convenient payment methods will not solve all of a firm’s problems when it comes to collections from clients. However, the easier law firms make it for clients to pay them, the more likely it is clients will pay their bills as soon as possible.

Jordan Rothman is a partner of [The Rothman Law Firm](http://www.rothman.law/), a full-service New York and New Jersey law firm. He is also the founder of [Student Debt Diaries](https://studentdebtdiaries.com/), a website discussing how he paid off his student loans. You can reach Jordan through email at [jordan@rothman.law](mailto:jordan@rothman.law?subject=Your%20ATL%20column).

# Above The Law 'Celebrities': Where Are They Now?
## Find out what happened to the stars of ten of Above the Law's biggest stories.
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)  
onSeptember 23, 2016 at 3:32 PMOctober 4, 2017 at 1:06 PM
9
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/above-the-law-celebrities-where-are-they-now/&text=Above%20The%20Law%20‘Celebrities’:%20Where%20Are%20They%20Now?)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/above-the-law-celebrities-where-are-they-now/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/above-the-law-celebrities-where-are-they-now/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Last month, Above the Law celebrated its [tenth anniversary](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/08/above-the-law-turns-ten-today-atl-celebrities-where-are-they-now/). You are all invited to our birthday party next week (details and RSVP [here](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/above-the-laws-10th-anniversary-party-youre-invited/)).

We are marking our tenth anniversary with [“10 for 10,”](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/atl-10-for-10/) a series of ten articles looking at how lawyers, the legal profession, and Above the Law have evolved over the past decade. In this story, which we previously [requested nominees for](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/08/above-the-law-turns-ten-today-atl-celebrities-where-are-they-now/), we will update you on the current whereabouts of ten ATL “celebrities” — the judges, lawyers, and law students featured in our biggest stories over the years. Think of it as the ATL version of that dearly departed VH1 show, [“Where Are They Now?”](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Where_Are_They_Now%3F_(U.S._TV_series))

Before we plunge into the list, a few caveats:

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
1. This list is admittedly idiosyncratic. People have strong views of who is or should be a “celebrity,” as well as whether they love or hate a particular celeb. We didn’t take a very formal approach to selecting these individuals. We started off by reviewing our biggest posts of all time, ranked by pageviews, and pulled some stars from those stories. But then we mixed in a few other figures who might not have appeared in a chart-topping individual story but served as recurring subjects of coverage.

2. This list excludes anonymous/pseudonymous people. It’s hard to determine what someone is up to when you don’t know their true identity. So you won’t see appearances here from Loyola 2L, our [2007 Lawyer of the Year](https://abovethelaw.com/2008/01/featured-survey-results-and-the-winners-are------/); Partner Emeritus, one of our most famous (or infamous) commenters, before we [removed comments](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/04/a-farewell-to-comments/); or “Ms. X,” the Biglaw mother with a [notoriously demanding schedule](https://abovethelaw.com/2012/11/departure-memo-of-the-day-parenting-gets-the-best-of-one-biglaw-associate/).

3. This list focuses on people who have at least somewhat interesting story arcs. There’s a reason you won’t see any of our Lawyer of the Year winners on this list. If you look up the past [LOTY honorees](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/01/above-the-laws-2015-lawyer-of-the-year-contest-the-winner/), you’ll see that almost all are doing what they were doing at the time that we honored them.

4. This list might contain errors or omissions. We tried our best to track people down, but we didn’t go to the ends of the earth (or even hire a [private investigator](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/08/the-art-of-fact-investigation-an-interview-with-philip-segal/)), so some of the information below might be incorrect or incomplete. But we will rely upon a method that has stood Above the Law in good stead over the past decade: crowdsourcing. If you have an addition or correction to any of the info below, please [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=Where%20Are%20They%20Now) or text us (646-820-8477), including the words “where are they now” somewhere in your message. We will then update accordingly.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
And now, on to our ten celebrities — actually more than ten, because we have some couples — and where they are now. We present them in no particular order.

1. [Judge Wade McCree](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/judge-wade-mccree/). We have covered many judicial scandals over the years, but this [2014 story about then-Judge McCree](https://abovethelaw.com/2014/07/shirtless-wade-mccree-may-be-heading-to-the-supreme-court/) is the most widely read of them all (thanks in large part to a link from the [Drudge Report](http://drudgereport.com/)). You might recall McCree for his penchant for posing for shirtless selfies, or the affair he was having with the complaining witness in a felony child support case that was before him.

What’s the latest on Wade McCree? He’s no longer “Judge” McCree; the Michigan Supreme Court tossed him from office in 2014. He’s not even a practicing lawyer; in February of this year, the State of Michigan Attorney Discipline Board [suspended his law license](http://www.law360.com/articles/753195/ex-judge-s-law-license-suspended-for-affair-with-litigant) for two years. But let’s look on the bright side: the Sixth Circuit held that the doctrine of judicial immunity protected McCree from a suit filed by the father in that child support case, and last year the Supreme Court [denied certiorari](http://www.law360.com/articles/615017). Congratulations?

2. [Justice Lori Douglas](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/lori-douglas/). Justice Douglas is the retired Canadian jurist who became an international news story — and one of our [most-read posts](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/01/judge-whose-nude-photos-got-posted-online-breaks-her-silence/) — after pornographic photos of her became public. It was covered as a scandal, and investigated as one too — to the tune of more than [$3 million](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/01/judge-whose-nude-photos-got-posted-online-breaks-her-silence/) in taxpayer money.

But with the benefit of hindsight, I’d say this is a story that we (and many others) got wrong, at least in our initial, breathless coverage. We later learned that Justice Douglas was more victim than vixen: it turned out that her (now deceased) husband, Jack King, shared the photos with others without Justice Douglas’s knowledge or consent.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
The good news is that Justice Douglas made it through this controversy and is doing [just fine today](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/01/judge-whose-nude-photos-got-posted-online-breaks-her-silence/?rf=1). The ethics investigation concluded with a settlement that ended the inquiry and allowed her to resign from the bench in May 2015 — an important date, because it allowed her to receive retirement benefits based on 10 years of judicial service.

Douglas is now back to practicing family law and hoping to do some teaching too. As she told the [Canadian Lawyer](http://www.canadianlawyermag.com/5876/Behind-the-headlines.html) earlier this year, “I feel fine. I haven’t been so well now for five years.”

3. [Reema Bajaj](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/reema-bajaj/). Sticking to the subject of “lawyers and sex,” this Illinois attorney made headlines after she was accused of moonlighting as a prostitute. In June 2012, she [pleaded guilty](https://abovethelaw.com/2012/06/down-goes-bajaj-reema-pleads-guilty-to-prostitution/) to a misdemeanor charge of prostitution. As of December 2013, she was working in an office in a managerial capacity and “moving on with her life,” as her lawyer [put it](http://www.daily-chronicle.com/2013/12/31/attorney-accused-of-prostitution-drops-lawsuit-over-nude-photos/abusj/).

In March 2014, Bajaj was [suspended from the practice of law](https://www.iardc.org/ldetail.asp?id=927701632) for three years and until further order of the Illinois Supreme Court. But March 2017 is just around the corner. Might the legal profession see a return of Reema? I hope that she’s allowed to return to practice (if she so desires); everyone deserves a second chance.

4. [Stephanie Grace](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/stephanie-grace/). This very bright young lawyer, a graduate of Princeton and Harvard Law School, generated nationwide controversy after an [unfortunate email of hers](https://abovethelaw.com/2010/04/hls-3ls-racist-email-goes-national/) that [some saw as racist](https://abovethelaw.com/2010/04/harvard-blsa-racism-banality-evil/) got dug up and disseminated (possibly by a [friend turned enemy](https://abovethelaw.com/2010/05/the-harvard-email-controversy-how-it-all-began/)).

Fortunately for Grace, some impressive employers looked past the controversy. Grace clerked for one of the most highly regarded judges in the country, Judge Alex Kozinski of the Ninth Circuit, and today works for [Latham & Watkins in San Diego](https://www.lw.com/people/StephanieNGrace), where she handles complex litigation (plus pro bono work too).

5. [Johnathan Perkins](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/johnathan-perkins/). This is another race-related story, but of a very different type. While he was a student at UVA Law School, Perkins admitted to [fabricating a story](https://abovethelaw.com/2011/05/a-law-student-plays-the-race-card-and-gets-busted-big-time/) about being harassed by UVA police on account of his race (he is African-American). His justification: “I wrote the article to bring attention to the topic of police misconduct.”

(Please don’t misconstrue this as a defense of his (clearly unacceptable) actions, but let me toss something out there: in the wake of Black Lives Matter movement and the widespread mistreatment of African-Americans by police that it has highlighted, doesn’t Perkins seem oddly prescient?)

Furious fellow UVA students argued that Perkins [shouldn’t be allowed to graduate](https://abovethelaw.com/2011/05/a-law-student-plays-the-race-card-and-gets-busted-big-time/), citing UVA’s strict honor code. But a jury of his peers acquitted him in those proceedings, and he did [receive his law degree](https://abovethelaw.com/2012/01/an-update-on-johnathan-perkins-did-he-get-his-law-degree/).

Like Stephanie Grace, Johnathan Perkins has been able to put the unpleasantness behind him and enjoy a successful legal career. He was admitted to the Pennsylvania bar and today is an associate in the [Philadelphia office of Montgomery McCracken](http://www.mmwr.com/attorney/johnathan-s-perkins/). He has taken lemons and made lemonade: he focuses on “representing universities and corporations with respect to claims of discrimination,” and he lists “higher education” as one of his practice areas as well.

UPDATE (10/3/2017): We now know much more about what happened to Johnathan Perkins back in 2011 than we did at the time, and it majorly changes how he and the situation should be viewed. See this new story, [Was UVA Law Alum Johnathan Perkins Pressured By The FBI Into Recanting His Account Of Racial Profiling?](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/09/was-uva-law-alum-johnathan-perkins-pressured-by-the-fbi-into-recanting-his-account-of-racial-profiling/?rf=1)

(Flip to the next page to read about Aaron Charney, Alexandra Marchuk, and other Above the Law mini-celebrities.)

# Flexibility Is A Two-Way Street When It Comes To This Biglaw Firm's Reopening Plans
## The firm's managing partner has no plans to micromanage anyone's schedule.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 8, 2021 at 12:47 PMJune 9, 2021 at 2:34 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/arent-fox-reopening/&text=Flexibility%20Is%20A%20Two-Way%20Street%20When%20It%20Comes%20To%20This%20Biglaw%20Firm’s%20Reopening%20Plans)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/arent-fox-reopening/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/arent-fox-reopening/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
When it comes to reopening plans in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, it looks like the majority of Biglaw firms are going with a phased-in approach to their return to the office. Flexibility remains a priority at most firms, and the only thing up in the air is the number of days employees will have to be physically present in the office. Now that a bit of uniformity seems to have been established in the market, let’s check in with another firm to see what they’ve got planned.

Arent Fox — ranked No. 107 in the most recent Am Law 200, with a 2020 gross revenue of $333,600,000 — recently announced its own phased-in return to the office. “The goal is for Arent Fox to be fully open as of September—after Labor Day,” said managing partner Cristina Carvalho in an interview with the American Lawyer. On July 6, all of the firm’s U.S offices will be open, and according to Carvalho, employees will likely come in once a week, and eventually, work their way up to coming in twice a week. While it’s expected that all personnel will maintain a “routine physical presence” in the office when the firm has fully reopened, flexibility is still on the table.

Carvalho said Arent Fox isn’t planning to define for staff and lawyers how many days they must spend in the office. Instead, she is confident that colleagues will find a mix that suits them, both personally and professionally.

“It’s not my intention to micromanage and say which day people are going to be in the office. Ultimately, we all understand what we need to do and, ultimately, we’re all here in the business of servicing our clients. Everybody at the firm has good judgment. And everyone will keep that ultimate goal in mind,” said Carvalho, who added that some staff and practice areas with responsibilities will likely find they need to spend more time in the office, but that the decision will be left to the individual and their managers.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Calvalho noted that flexibility must be a two-way street. “The firm will provide for a flexible schedule for everyone but, lawyers and the staff should also be flexible,” she said. “Sometimes there’s emergency situations or impromptu meetings or client demands where colleagues might need to make unscheduled trips in. That’s the nature of the business.”

What has your firm announced as far as a reopening plan is concerned? The more information is out there, the more likely it is that firms will be able to establish a market standard for a return to work.

As soon as you find out about the reopening plan at your firm, please [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Office%20Reopening) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Office Reopening”) or text us at (646) 820-8477. We always keep our sources on stories anonymous. There’s no need to send a memo (if one exists) using your firm email account; your personal email account is fine. If a memo has been circulated, please be sure to include it as proof; we like to post complete memos as a service to our readers. You can take a photo of the memo and attach as a picture if you are worried about metadata in a PDF or Word file. Thanks.

# The Biglaw Firms Behind The Abortion Defense Network
## The top of Biglaw getting together for an excellent cause.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onFebruary 24, 2023 at 7:47 PMFebruary 24, 2023 at 1:13 PM
3
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/02/the-biglaw-firms-behind-the-abortion-defense-network/&text=The%20Biglaw%20Firms%20Behind%20The%20Abortion%20Defense%20Network)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/02/the-biglaw-firms-behind-the-abortion-defense-network/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/02/the-biglaw-firms-behind-the-abortion-defense-network/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))


Ed. Note: Welcome to our daily feature [Trivia Question of the Day!](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/trivia-question-of-the-day/)

This week, which eight Biglaw firms launched the Abortion Defense Network?

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)

ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Hint: Nancy Northup, president and CEO of the Center for Reproductive Rights, said, “Many states have conflicting and overlapping abortion bans that make it nearly impossible to know what is legal and what is not. People are worried they may be prosecuted even for helping someone find abortion services across state lines. This initiative brings together some of the best lawyers in the country to provide legal advice, as well as criminal and civil defense.”

See the answer on the next page.

From Pilot and Above The Law

# Dropbox For Lawyers: What Are You Risking?
## Five questions you should always ask a service provider when moving a law firm to the cloud. 
By NetDocuments and Above the Law  
onDecember 20, 2022 at 3:03 PMDecember 20, 2022 at 2:00 PM
5
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/dropbox-for-lawyers-what-are-you-risking/&text=Dropbox%20For%20Lawyers:%20What%20Are%20You%20Risking?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/dropbox-for-lawyers-what-are-you-risking/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/dropbox-for-lawyers-what-are-you-risking/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Simply put, commercial storage options like Dropbox and Google Drive can be risky. 

They are not built to address the specific needs and requirements of lawyers and legal teams, particularly as they pertain to security and compliance requirements. 

And while some solutions offer flexibility, the lack of controls can quickly turn document organization into a nightmare.

In this eBook, our friends at NetDocuments explore commercial and legal-centric cloud technology applications, which continue to grow in popularity for lawyers. 

Download it to learn:

- Why firms are moving to the cloud
- 5 questions to always ask a service provider
- Drawbacks of commercial solutions
- How a legal-centric application can help
Download Now

By filling out the form, you are opting in to receive communication from Above the Law and its partners.

####Topics
[Biglaw](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/biglaw/), [Boutique Law Firms](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/boutique-law-firms/), [NetDocuments](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/netdocuments/), [Small Law Firms](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/small-law-firms-topic/), [Sponsored Content](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/sponsored-content/), [Technology](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/technology/)

# Another Magical Bonus Announcement
## Welcome to A&O.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onApril 20, 2021 at 10:43 AMApril 20, 2021 at 10:28 AM
12
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/ao-special-bonuses-2021/&text=Another%20Magical%20Bonus%20Announcement)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/ao-special-bonuses-2021/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/ao-special-bonuses-2021/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
It’s been almost three weeks since Freshfields became the first Magic Circle firm to [join the latest round of special bonuses](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/freshfields-special-bonus-2021/). But with Allen & Overy joining the bunch yesterday, associates are noting “a little late to the game but better late than never!”

Indeed, [you could have gotten a hat](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/biglaw-firm-says-youre-expecting-a-bonus-but-please-accept-this-hat-instead/).

So what we have here is a backloaded June and “Fall” bonus.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  


What does “Fall” mean? It’s unclear. June isn’t exactly crystal clear either, with the memo only saying that the firm anticipates bonuses will be paid by June 30. For a firm that’s had three weeks to consider what its peers are doing, you’d think they’d have worked out more of the logistical kinks.

In any event, welcome news.

Please help us help you when it comes to bonus news at other firms. As soon as your firm’s bonus memo comes out, please [email it to us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Bonus) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Bonus”) or text us (646-820-8477). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

# Third Woman With Allegations Against Former DLA Piper Partner Says He's A Bully Who Called Her A 'Dumb B*tch'
## The allegations against the former partner are piling up.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onOctober 23, 2019 at 1:14 PMOctober 24, 2019 at 1:21 PM
7
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/10/third-woman-with-allegations-against-former-dla-piper-partner-says-hes-a-bully-who-called-her-a-dumb-btch/&text=Third%20Woman%20With%20Allegations%20Against%20Former%20DLA%20Piper%20Partner%20Says%20He’s%20A%20Bully%20Who%20Called%20Her%20A%20‘Dumb%20B*tch’)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/10/third-woman-with-allegations-against-former-dla-piper-partner-says-hes-a-bully-who-called-her-a-dumb-btch/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/10/third-woman-with-allegations-against-former-dla-piper-partner-says-hes-a-bully-who-called-her-a-dumb-btch/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Louis Lehot

A third woman has come [forward to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ](http://www.wigdorlaw.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Letter-from-L.-Christensen-to-EEOC-10.23.19.pdf)with allegations about the inappropriate behavior of former DLA Piper partner Louis Lehot.[ Leah M. Christensen](https://www.sandiego.edu/law/faculty/biography.php?profile_id=7037), a professor at the University of San Diego School of Law and former Professional Responsibility Counsel within the firm’s Office of General Counsel, claims Lehot acted like a “textbook bully” and was allowed to get away with it because of the size of his book of business, saying:

Lehot is a textbook bully. There is simply no other way to describe him. He bulldozed his way through DLA Piper like a tank, rolling over anything or anyone in his way. In order to get his way, Lehot yelled, threatened, intimidated and terrorized people around him. I know because I was one of the people around him.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
She also says that when, in the course of her work, she spoke with Lehot about his interpretation of an ethics rule, he lashed out calling her a “dumb bitch”:

For example, one time when I told Lehot that he was not following the ethics rules, in front of other DLA staff, Lehot called me a “dumb bitch.” I reported Lehot’s abusive conduct and “loose” interpretation of the ethics rules during our weekly department meetings to my boss, Peter Lindau, Assistant General Counsel, and to Joe Davis, Associate General Counsel. Nothing was done.

The allegations against Lehot are starting to pile up. Earlier this month, DLA Piper partner Vanina Guerrero [alleged that Lehot repeatedly sexually assaulted her.](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/10/dla-piper-partner-accused-of-sexual-assault-by-fellow-partner/) She asked the firm to release her from their mandatory arbitration agreement so she can pursue her claims in court. The firm has been conspicuously silent on the forced arbitration agreement — despite the [attention their arbitration stance](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/10/kamala-harris-gets-dragged-into-dla-piper-sexual-assault-controversy/) in this case [has garnered](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/10/law-school-students-protest-outside-of-dla-piper-over-alleged-sexual-assault/), but, they did announce that Lehot had been [let go from the firm.](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/10/dla-piper-partner-out-amid-sexual-assault-allegations/) But the firm also put Guerrero on [administrative leave](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/10/now-the-dla-piper-accuser-has-been-put-on-leave/), saying they’d uncovered allegations against her unrelated to Lehot during their investigation of her claims. Lehot[ released a statement](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/10/dla-piper-partner-accused-of-sexual-assault-speaks-out/) contesting the allegations against him and saying Guerrero was “exploiting” the #MeToo movement. Then a second woman, an anonymous HR manager, came forward with her own allegations against Lehot,[ saying he made her “physically afraid,”](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/10/second-woman-accuses-former-dla-piper-partner-of-inappropriate-behavior/?rf=1) and further alleging the firm let her go when she complained about Lehot.

As part of Christensen’s letter to the EEOC, she also says she’s been contacted by other women at the firm who’ve had similar experiences with Lehot but are “too scared” to come forward.

# More Plaintiffs Added To Astonishing Pregnancy And Gender Discrimination Case Against MoFo
## A spokesperson for the firm calls the allegations 'inconsistent' with the firm's values.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJanuary 28, 2019 at 5:44 PMJune 6, 2019 at 3:34 PM
81
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/01/more-plaintiffs-added-to-astonishing-pregnancy-and-gender-discrimination-case-against-mofo/&text=More%20Plaintiffs%20Added%20To%20Astonishing%20Pregnancy%20And%20Gender%20Discrimination%20Case%20Against%20MoFo)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/01/more-plaintiffs-added-to-astonishing-pregnancy-and-gender-discrimination-case-against-mofo/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/01/more-plaintiffs-added-to-astonishing-pregnancy-and-gender-discrimination-case-against-mofo/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Back in April, three women sued Biglaw giant Morrison & Foerster in[ a $100 million class-action case claiming the firm engaged in gender discrimination](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/mofo-hit-with-100-million-pregnancy-discrimination-lawsuit/?rf=1) against women who are pregnant or have children. The action was initiated by three Jane Doe attorneys at the firm who said when they took maternity leave they were placed on a “mommy track” from which their careers couldn’t recover. Last week, Sanford Heisler Sharp, attorneys for the plaintiffs, filed an amended complaint, adding three more Jane Doe plaintiffs to the complaint.

According to the amended complaint, in stark contrast to its reputation (MoFo was named a [Top 10 Female Friendly Firm by Yale Law Women in 2018](https://biglawbusiness.com/yale-law-women-names-top-10-female-friendly-firms)), taking maternity leave is a “dead end” for women’s careers at the firm:

At MoFo, the mommy track is a dead end. Not only are pregnant attorneys and mothers routinely prevented from advancing with their class years, but the Firm forces women who are or could be mothers to work harder to prove that they are dedicated to their positions and to the Firm, setting unreasonably high expectations for them. Those who avail themselves of the Firm’s maternity leave or flexible work schedule policy (voluntarily or involuntarily) — which permits attorneys to work part-time to care for their newborn children, purportedly without fear of repercussions for their career — are particularly vulnerable. Adding insult to injury, women are often denied even the chance to meet these expectations when they return from maternity leave and find themselves without sufficient work to meet the billable hour expectations set by the Firm.

The complaint goes on to detail specifics for each of the plaintiffs, including one, Jane Doe 5, who was named a “Pro Bono All-Star” by the firm prior to her maternity leave. After she came back to the firm, the complaint alleges all that changed:

Upon returning from leave, Jane Doe 5 learned that she had not been promoted with her peers, nor had she received the corresponding salary and bonus increase that should have accompanied her anticipated promotion. Prior to that, Jane Doe 5’s supervisors had given her no indication or notice that the Firm would not progress her. Jane Doe 5 had no history of performance issues nor had she ever been held back previously during her time at MoFo.

The amended complaint goes on to allege that despite being encouraged to take a flexible schedule in the months after returning from leave, Jane Doe 5 was fired six months after she returned from maternity leave. According to the filing, the partners who communicated the termination were unable to cite specific examples where her performance was lacking. The treatment of Jane Doe 5 — as well as the other Jane Doe plaintiffs — is being called “troubling” by their attorney, Aimee Krause Stewart:

“The material inequities for pregnant women and mothers that the Complaint lays out are bad enough,” said Aimee Krause Stewart, “but the gaslighting, humiliation and impossible choices our plaintiffs describe are even more troubling.”

A spokesperson for the firm refuted the allegations in the amended complaint, and called them “inconsistent” with the firm’s values:

The allegations about our firm in the amended complaint are not true. They are inconsistent with the facts, and our values, policies, and practices. We have fully investigated these claims and they are without foundation. We will vigorously defend our longstanding record of supporting and promoting women and parents.

We have been broadly recognized for our leadership in providing greater opportunity for women lawyers, including being named one of the top family-friendly and women-friendly firms by Yale Law Women and as a “Ceiling Crasher” by Law360, and we exceed the national average in every leadership metric included in Working Mother’s “Best Law Firms for Women” list. Our Firm’s commitment to – and track record on – diversity and inclusion remains one of our proudest achievements and greatest priorities.

Read the full amended complaint below.


Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, and host of [The Jabot podcast.](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA) AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter ([@Kathryn1](https://twitter.com/Kathryn1)).
